verses.text: When the day of Pentecost arrived, they were all together in one place.
verses.comment: Pentecost was a Jewish feast, fifty days after Passover. The disciples’ unity is emphasized, foreshadowing one united Church.

verses.text: Suddenly a sound like a mighty rushing wind came from heaven, and it filled the whole house where they were sitting.
verses.comment: Wind is a symbol of the Holy Spirit (John 3:8; Ezek. 37:9). The Spirit’s arrival marks fulfillment of prophecy.

verses.text: And divided tongues as of fire appeared to them and rested on each one of them.
verses.comment: Fire often represents God’s presence and purification (Matt. 3:11; Exod. 3:2). Every believer receives the Spirit.

verses.text: And they were all filled with the Holy Spirit and began to speak in other languages, as the Spirit gave them ability.
verses.comment: The Spirit’s filling empowers speech (Joel 2:29), connecting the gifts to the Church’s mission to all nations.

verses.text: Now there were dwelling in Jerusalem Jews, devout men from every nation under heaven.
verses.comment: This fulfills the promise to Abraham that all nations would be blessed (Genesis 12:3).

verses.text: And when this sound came, the crowd gathered, and they were bewildered because each one heard them speaking in his own language.
verses.comment: God reverses Babel’s confusion, gathering the nations into unity.

verses.text: They were astonished and amazed, saying, 'Are not all these who are speaking Galileans?'
verses.comment: Galileans were seen as uneducated. The Spirit overcomes all limitations.

verses.text: 'And how is it that we each hear, in our own native language?'
verses.comment: A sign that God’s message is for all peoples, fulfilling universal mission prophecies.

verses.text: 'Parthians and Medes and Elamites, and residents of Mesopotamia, Judea and Cappadocia, Pontus and Asia,'
verses.comment: The list of nations highlights the worldwide scope of the Church’s mission.

verses.text: 'Phrygia and Pamphylia, Egypt and parts of Libya near Cyrene, and visitors from Rome, both Jews and converts,'
verses.comment: Rome’s mention prefigures the prominence of the mission to Gentiles and the Church’s expansion.

verses.text: 'Cretans and Arabians— we hear them telling in our own languages the mighty works of God.'
verses.comment: The Spirit enables proclamation of God’s wonders to all. This foreshadows the gospel for all nations.

verses.text: And all were amazed and perplexed, saying to one another, 'What does this mean?'
verses.comment: Spiritual phenomena often provoke wonder and questions about God’s actions.

verses.text: But others mocked and said, 'They are filled with new wine.'
verses.comment: Spiritual gifts can be misunderstood or dismissed by those lacking faith.

verses.text: But Peter, standing with the eleven, lifted up his voice and addressed them: 'Men of Judea and all who dwell in Jerusalem, let this be known to you, and give ear to my words.'
verses.comment: Peter speaks with authority as the leader, fulfilling Christ’s appointment (Matt. 16:18-19).

verses.text: For these people are not drunk, as you suppose, since it is only the third hour of the day.
verses.comment: A reasonable explanation; the third hour is about 9 AM, too early for drunkenness.

verses.text: 'But this is what was spoken through the prophet Joel:'
verses.comment: Peter connects New Testament events with Old Testament prophecy, showing continuity of God’s plan.

verses.text: 'And in the last days it shall be, God says, that I will pour out my Spirit on all flesh, and your sons and your daughters shall prophesy, your young men shall see visions, and your old men shall dream dreams.'
verses.comment: The outpouring of the Spirit marks the era of salvation—fulfilled in the Church’s ongoing mission.

verses.text: 'Even on my male and female servants in those days I will pour out my Spirit, and they shall prophesy.'
verses.comment: God’s grace is given to all, regardless of status, reinforcing the universality of the Church.

verses.text: 'And I will show wonders in the heavens above and signs on the earth below, blood, and fire, and vapor of smoke;'
verses.comment: Signs echo God’s presence at Sinai (Exod. 19:18) and prophecies of the last days (Matt. 24:29).

verses.text: 'the sun will be turned to darkness and the moon to blood, before the great and glorious day of the Lord comes.'
verses.comment: Apocalyptic imagery; traditionally interpreted both literally and spiritually as signs of the New Covenant.

verses.text: 'And it shall come to pass that everyone who calls on the name of the Lord will be saved.'
verses.comment: Emphasizes the availability of salvation to all, an invitation to join the Church through faith and the sacraments.

verses.text: 'Men of Israel, listen to these words: Jesus of Nazareth, a man accredited by God to you by miracles, wonders, and signs that God did through him among you, as you yourselves know,'
verses.comment: Jesus’ miracles were confirmation of his divine mission, fulfilling prophecy (John 5:36).

verses.text: 'this Man, delivered up by the definite plan and foreknowledge of God, you crucified and killed by the hands of lawless men.'
verses.comment: The crucifixion was not accidental, but was part of God’s salvific plan (Isaiah 53:10; Mark 14:64).

verses.text: God raised him up, freeing him from the agony of death, because it was impossible for him to be held by its power.
verses.comment: Christ’s resurrection was foretold (Ps. 16:10) and shows his divinity and authority over life (John 10:17-18).

verses.text: 'For David says concerning him: I saw the Lord always before me, for he is at my right hand, so that I may not be shaken;'
verses.comment: Peter interprets David’s words as referring to Christ, a sign of messianic fulfillment.

verses.text: 'therefore my heart was glad and my tongue rejoiced; moreover, my flesh will also dwell in hope,'
verses.comment: David speaks beyond himself; the hope is fulfilled eternally in Christ’s resurrection.

verses.text: 'for you will not abandon my soul to Hades, nor let your Holy One see decay.'
verses.comment: Direct Old Testament prophecy of Jesus’ resurrection; his body did not see corruption.

verses.text: 'You have made known to me the path of life; you will fill me with joy in your presence.'
verses.comment: Resurrection brings eternal joy and communion with God.

verses.text: 'Brothers, I may confidently say to you about the patriarch David, that he died and was buried, and his tomb is with us to this day.'
verses.comment: Peter distinguishes David from Christ; the prophecy refers to someone greater.

verses.text: 'Being a prophet, and knowing that God had sworn an oath to him that he would set one of his descendants on his throne,'
verses.comment: Shows the messianic expectation rooted in God’s covenant with David.

verses.text: 'seeing this beforehand, David spoke of the resurrection of the Christ, that he was not abandoned to Hades, nor did his flesh see decay.'
verses.comment: David, as prophet, anticipates Christ’s resurrection, a foundation of Christian belief.

verses.text: This Jesus God raised up, and of that we all are witnesses.
verses.comment: Eyewitness testimony is an apostolic foundation, vital for succession of leadership and authority in the Church.

verses.text: Exalted at the right hand of God, having received from the Father the promised Holy Spirit, he has poured out this that you yourselves are seeing and hearing.
verses.comment: Christ’s exaltation and sending of the Spirit establish him as Lord of all and source of grace for the Church.

verses.text: For David did not ascend into the heavens; but he himself says: 'The Lord said to my Lord, "Sit at my right hand,"'
verses.comment: Affirms Christ’s divinity and kingship foretold in Psalm 110.

verses.text: 'until I make your enemies your footstool.'
verses.comment: Christ’s final victory and rule are central to the fulfillment of God’s kingdom on earth.

verses.text: Therefore let all the house of Israel know for certain that God has made him both Lord and Messiah, this Jesus whom you crucified.
verses.comment: Jesus is proclaimed as Lord (divine title) and Messiah, head of the Church and source of salvation.

verses.text: Now when they heard this, they were cut to the heart and said to Peter and the other apostles, 'Brothers, what shall we do?'
verses.comment: The Spirit convicts hearts; Peter responds as the Church’s shepherd guiding people to salvation.

verses.text: And Peter said to them, 'Repent and be baptized, every one of you, in the name of Jesus Christ for the forgiveness of your sins, and you will receive the gift of the Holy Spirit.'
verses.comment: Peter emphasizes repentance and baptism for forgiveness and receiving the Spirit (see John 3:5; Matt. 28:19). Baptism as necessary for entrance into the Church is strongly implied.

verses.text: 'For the promise is for you and your children and for all who are far off, everyone whom the Lord our God calls to himself.'
verses.comment: God’s promise extends through generations, not just individuals—hinting at a communal and sacramental faith.

verses.text: And with many other words he bore witness and continued to urge them, saying, 'Save yourselves from this corrupt generation.'
verses.comment: Motivates ongoing conversion and separation from sinful influences. Perseverance in faith is necessary.

verses.text: So those who received his word were baptized, and about three thousand souls were added that day.
verses.comment: Baptism marks formal entrance into the community; the Church grows through sacramental initiation.

verses.text: And they continued steadfastly in the apostles’ teaching and fellowship, in the breaking of bread, and in prayers.
verses.comment: "Breaking of bread" refers to the Eucharist, a central mystery of the early Church. Apostolic teaching and communal worship define Christian worship.

verses.text: And awe came upon every soul, and many wonders and signs were being done through the apostles.
verses.comment: Signs and miracles express God’s ongoing work through the apostolic leadership.

verses.text: And all who believed were together and had all things in common.
verses.comment: Emphasizes unity, charity, and fellowship—marks of the true Church.

verses.text: And they were selling their possessions and belongings and distributing the proceeds to all, as anyone had need.
verses.comment: Radical generosity flows from faith. The early Church cared for its members materially and spiritually.

verses.text: And day by day, attending the temple together and breaking bread in their homes, they received their food with glad and sincere hearts,
verses.comment: Both temple worship and Eucharist in homes show a continuity between old and new covenants; daily communal worship is central.

verses.text: praising God and having favor with all the people. And the Lord added to their number day by day those who were being saved.
verses.comment: The Church’s growth is attributed to God’s action. Salvation is a continual process within the believing community.
